Mail completed form to HIM at 1304 Franklin Ave., Normal, IL 61761

forms.document_type: ROI authorization form (general, Carle Health system-level)
ROI authorization form (behavioral health, BroMenn campus)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a generic ROI authorization PDF, prints and fills it by hand, then mails or delivers it to the HIM department; records can be delivered via mail, in-person pickup, or MyCarle Account.

red_flags: Purpose of disclosure required — potentially non-compliant with HIPAA Right of Access for patient self-requests
SSN (last 4 digits) field not marked as optional
Behavioral health form (form-3) requires witness signature for authorization and revocation, exceeding HIPAA requirements
bright_spots: MyCarle Account electronic delivery option for received records (30-day availability)
Explicit HIPAA Right of Access citation (CFR 164.524) on general forms
Granular record-type selection with 30+ categories across hospitalization and clinic columns
Easy direct PDF download with no login wall or bot blocking

findability.rationale: Level 4: Forms were easy to find via basic web search with direct PDF download links; carle.org medical records page links to them — no login or complex navigation required.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2: Primarily a paper workflow — digitally-authored PDFs have zero fillable fields, requiring print-and-handwrite; submission is limited to physical mail or in-person delivery with no fax, email, or portal submission option.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Well-organized logical flow with granular record-type options, but cramped single-page layout with small font (~8-9pt legal text), limited write-in space, and dense legalese without a plain-language summary.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the generic ROI form but it was not designed for patient self-access; the 'To Send to / To Request from' framing, required purpose-of-disclosure field, and lack of a dedicated patient access pathway mean patients must figure out which parts apply to them.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Purpose-of-disclosure requirement may exceed HIPAA limits for patient access; SSN field not marked optional; vague fee disclosure; behavioral health form adds witness requirements beyond what HIPAA mandates — offset by explicit CFR 164.524 citation and proper treatment-conditioning disclaimer.

overall.summary: Carle BroMenn provides easily findable but functionally paper-based ROI forms that use a generic authorization design without differentiating patient self-access from third-party release, resulting in a middling patient experience.
